author: Sarah Edworthy
title: Weddings in Greece: best locations on where to get married
text: More holiday options in Greece Every bride dreams of the most romantic scenario for the Big Day – a stunning location, the perfect ceremony, a cake of towering confectionery, a secluded honeymoon – and wedding fantasies do not come more idyllic than those you can plan in Greece. Here, in land of knockout settings and exuberant hospitality, you can find nuptial paradise on a hideaway island, on the beach, in a vineyard, aboard a boat or in a fairy-tale castle. Santorini Travel to church on the back of a donkey This dramatically glamorous volcanic island with its boutique hotels and charming rural blue-domed churches boasts a sophisticated wedding-planning directory to keep arrangements worry-free. Whether you want a civil, religious or a vow-renewal ceremony, local coordinators offer tailor-made packages to fit your budget, helping with legal arrangements, booking for officiant/venue/priest/church, flowers, wedding dinner, reception, cake, music, dancers, fireworks, photographer and videographer, accommodation, transport, excursions, and so on. The island’s legendary nightclubs are on hand to dance the night away. Monemvasia Say ‘I do’ in a medieval castle or Byzantine church This castle town of cobbled lanes and romantic balconies on the eastern coast of Laconia in the Peloponnese – carved into the rock of an islet connected to the mainland by a narrow bridge – makes an otherworldly wedding/honeymoon location. Steeped in romance: Monemvasia Photo: Region of Peloponnese Once through the imposing gate, you are steeped in romance and the history of princes and emperors. You can marry within the fortress, on a sandy beach or on a terrace overlooking the Aegean Sea. Nafplio A Venetian spectacular amid fountains and bougainvillea Natural beauty, romance and a comfortable stay are all to be found in this seaside town located in the northeast of the Peloponnese. History exudes from its three fortresses: Akronafplia (Bronze Age), Palamidi (a jewel of a baroque citadel) and Bourtzi (located on a small island in front of the town port, accessible by boat). Surrounded by groves of oranges and olives, ancient ruins and the stunning theatre of Epidaurus, Nafplio is rich in options for honeymoon adventure. Rethymno Lose your heart to Crete With a dreamy atmosphere, splendid medieval churches and gorgeous wedding venues for civil ceremony and reception, Rethymno also provides a wedding party with the perfect holiday destination: crystal-clear seas, breath-taking sunset views and traditional Cretan specialities. Lindos, Rhodes island Find the ultimate beach wedding on the shores of Rhodes Civil and orthodox ceremonies can be arranged at the pretty chapel in St Paul’s Bay with a breathtaking view to the acropolis of Lindos Castle with its famous Temple of Athena Lindia. Transport is restricted to donkey and moped in this village of whitewashed houses and cobbled streets. It’s a magical destination to be ‘in situ’ to honeymoon with plenty of water sports to enjoy at the beaches of Lardou, Glistra, Gennadi and Kiotari. Parga Plan a dreamy ceremony in a majestic Venetian castle Nestled beneath a mighty fortress, the town of Parga in the Epirus region is washed by the Ionian Sea and close to notable archaeological sites. A multitude of hotels and restaurants are geared up for reception parties. As a backdrop to wedding photographs, the view from the castle, overlooking the sea and the lush island of Panagia with its charming chapel is hard to better. Hydra Honeymoon in one of Greece's most romantic destinations Hydra, built in the shape of an amphitheatre on a slope overlooking the Argosaronic Gulf, boasts stone mansions, picturesque lanes and secluded squares. Transport is exclusively by donkey, which preserves a timeless atmosphere on an island rich in waterfront history, grandeur, museums, idyllic beaches and romantic cafes. A place of pilgrimage for yachties, Hydra was immortalised as the location for the film Boy on a Dolphin , shot on the island in 1957 with Sophia Loren. • Read more about Greek travel at Holidays in Greece
